bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 1, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the relationship between L. icteroides and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 1, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B
Noguchi
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 1, 1923.
/LC
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I was glad to get the Memorandum of the results of Pfeiffer
tests of Hanson and Iglesias.

The result tentds to substantiate the claim of L. icteroides as
the causative organism of yellow fever and, if any considerable num-
ber of observations give the same result, to give us a most valuable
laboratory diagnosis as to whether one has had yellow fever. This is
of fully as much value from a sanitary standpoint as a laboratory diag-
nosis during the attack, indeed considering how frequently facilities
for the latter would be lacking--more valuable.
